Tim, this is the bug I mentioned yesterday. It looks like the environment is getting closed out and then used again later, so the _astRoot is null on the second pass.

I was able to reproduce this locally, but only by using an annotation processor that incorrectly cached a type between builds. Is it possible the annotation processor you're using is doing that? Do you have the source to it?

I built the annotation processor myself, and perhaps I'm doing something illegal.  Let me give you an explaination of what the processor does and you can let me know if it was designed to do this.  Basically it's just a java beans BeanInfo generator.

1. I loop through all of the type declarations in the environment to get a list of classes that need a BeanInfo class generated for it.  This includes all classes that contain a supported Annotation type in the factory and are concrete.
2. I loop through the entire inheritance tree for each of the Classes that I found in step 1 and record all of the annotations for each Class, method and parameter in a custom data structure.
3. I then merge together all of the annotations in the custom data structure I created in step 2 based on which annotation appears at the most recently overriden level.
4. Finally, I write out a BeanInfo source for each class.
5. The processor ends.

I'm not sure what type of caching might be the problem.  Do you mean if you were saving a copy of an InterfaceDeclaration, ClassDeclaration or TypeDeclaration in a static variable and then refurring to it on a subsequent run of the processor?  

I do have a static object that keeps all of my custom data structures in it, that has some XXXDeclarations kept in it.

I'll try to clear out all of my static objects on every processor run to see if that helps.  

Sorry in advance if this turns out to be the problem...

Wes G.

(In reply to comment #9)
> I built the annotation processor myself, and perhaps I'm doing something
> illegal.  Let me give you an explaination of what the processor does and you
> can let me know if it was designed to do this.  Basically it's just a java
> beans BeanInfo generator.
> 
> 1. I loop through all of the type declarations in the environment to get a list
> of classes that need a BeanInfo class generated for it.  This includes all
> classes that contain a supported Annotation type in the factory and are
> concrete.

Instead of doing this, you want to call AnnotationProcessorEnvirionment.getDeclarationsAnnoatatedWith(AnnotationTypeDeclaration);

Call this everytime your process() method is called. Do not hold the results of this between calls to process.

> Instead of doing this, you want to call
> AnnotationProcessorEnvirionment.getDeclarationsAnnoatatedWith(AnnotationTypeDeclaration);
> Call this everytime your process() method is called. Do not hold the results of
> this between calls to process.
Thanks for the info.  I think this was the problem.

It was never my intent to cache the results between calls, it was just a failure to clear() out my static data strutures between the calls to the process().  I have changed this bug to an enhancement since an assertion failure might be nice for those that don't follow the internals of the JDT/ADT.  It might also save others time to know immediately what they are doing wrong.  If this doesn't make sense, it can be closed.
Thanks, Wes. Your suggestion makes perfect sense: we'll change this from an NPE to an AssertionError or an IllegalStateException with info about why it could happen.
Fixed in HEAD. We now throw an IllegalStateException in this condition rather than an NPE.
